title: Who will win the 2020 Bolivian presidential election?
preds: Last polling had Arce 15 points ahead of both Anez and Mesa.  Subsequent polling of how each have weathered Covid crisis also puts Arce on top. So seems probable Arce will lead first round. Arce seems more likely than not to win a runoff against either Anez or Mesa. Emerging doubts about fraud allegations that prompted Morales’ departure and sense of injustice arising may strengthen Arce further since he is running for Morales’ MAS party.
Less than two weeks to go and no election date set yet.
Still no word on an election date, we have two weeks to go in this challenge.

Down a bit on Anez...New Associated Press article suggests corrupt Bolivia ventilator deal could hurt Anez presidential 
 hopes. Link https://apnews.com/a240ff413fb23220aff30c6d6e6aba4c?utm_source=piano&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=morningwire&pnespid=0eNopvlXH1CNw4A3sHCpXJO4.hDrW14zU.Om5S97
Three weeks until question closes and not a peep about elections being rescheudled yet as far as I know.
Arg! I keep re-reading this about the extension date and it sounds like it will close June 14th but if the before is really after in the sentence it makes a lot more sense. Will modify somewhat.
Ok my understanding is it will close June 14th. No election by then.
The longer the election is delayed the better the chances for Anez one would think. The June 13 deadline is now only 22 days away and no mention of an election I can find.

Bolivian press reports Evo's MAS party already complaining about manipulation of mechanical vote, even though elections will not be held until after health emergency is officially ended  link https://www.eldiario.net/noticias/2020/2020_05/nt200522/politica.php?n=40&-demandan-distribucion-equitativa-de-escanios   but it takes a vote manipulator to know one... Also, as long as Anez gets wherself promoted in media as "the president" she becomes more difficult to unseat in an electoral contest whenever that happens... the photo helps  link https://www.eldiario.net/noticias/2020/20 20_05/nt200522/politica.php?n=41&-presidenta-aniez-ordena-auditoria-de-compras
isigh
At the same time, political scandal can work against Anez. As this link in Spanish indicates, her health minister was arrested recently for buying respirators at highly inflated prices, something that is happening elsewhere in Latin America  http://www.laprensa.com.ar/489052-Detienen-al-ministro-de-Salud-de-Bolivia-por-la-compra-de-respiradores-con-sobreprecios.note.aspx

GJP might want to look around to confirm the official date(s) the election(s) are going to take place. This soucre link says the time frame is apparently set for August, and that Covid-19 is a reason for the date change,,  and that how the candidates approach the political economy of lithium, may play a deciding factor . Draw your own conclusions.  https://dialogochino.net/en/extractive-industries/35423-bolivia-rethinks-how-to-industrialize-its-lithium-amid-political-transition/?utm_source=Di%C3%A1logo+Chino+Bolet%C3%ADn&utm_campaign=22cb0c67f3-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2019_03_20_02_05_COPY_01&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_8a71d40dce-22cb0c67f3-46847241&mc_cid=22cb0c67f3&mc_eid=0b946cee04

Bolivia currently has over 4000 covid-19 cases and over 250 new daily. For a country with limited capacity lockdown appears to be the only short term effective remediation. So assume election unlikely in May or early June.

Don’t you mean after rather than before? That is why I put 100% on another outcome. If the Bolivian election takes place before the scheduled closing date of the question, then the question's closing date will be extended out to cover the new runoff date (if needed). Changing a bit because this is confused.

Very doubtful if the election will be held by June 13 at this point. Ms. Anez is comfortable in her interim position and so are 69% of the people even with a severe lockdown in place. The legislature has decreed an election must occur before August 2, which is outside the timelline of this question.
Boliva postpones voting due to covid-19, currently 1886 cases with 84 new per day. If the number of new cases continues to drop, it will be harder to postpone the election.

The acting President proposed to delay the election due to virus, congress says it should happen in August.
https://www.ft.com/content/0b28f850-a133-4ea5-925e-b6722acfdece
President says NO there is no set date at present.
My assumption no election by the June 13 end of this question. Bolivia has 1470 cases with over 240 a day new.

Does this mean this will close June 14th if there is no election before then or will it be extended if a date is known? Confusing:  If the Bolivian election takes place before the scheduled closing date of the question, then the question's closing date will be extended out to cover the new runoff date (if needed).

Evo's sorched earth policy of burning Bolivian "rain forest" to plant "cash crops" is becoming cannonfodder for NGOs and fake newsniks and could be used to damage the political "brand" of any of the candidates.  Link https://en.mercopress.com/2020/05/02/marked-increase-of-forest-fires-in-bolivia-claim-environmentalists?utm_source=feed&utm_medium=rss&utm_content=main&utm_campaign=rss&utm_source=MercoPress+Latest+News&utm_campaign=c40752d8de-RSS_EMAIL_CAMPAIGN&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_f95ead9f0a-c40752d8de-71648993

Still assuming no new election date has been set. 
Covid-19 cases = more than a thousand cases with more than 50 new per day currently.
A very confusing situation with a postponed election and no new date set.

26 March 2020 the Bolivian spanish language newspaper-online "Pagina Siete" quotes the head of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal to wit that presidential election(s)  will be held between 7 June and 6 September.   Polls you can google dated 20 March in Wikipedia (keywords Bolivia presidential election) show no clear "first round winner."  Who powerful neighbor and trade partner Brazil, and the White House would like to see become president of Bolivia may also factor into the final outcome. Then too, there may another "postponement."
Assuming that the election will not be held within the parameters of this question.

Movement Towards Socialism party (MAS), are preferred candidates in the general elections set to be held on May 3 (https://peoplesdispatch.org/2020/03/19/mas-candidates-lead-in-opinion-polls-ahead-of-general-elections-in-bolivia/).  Earlier polls show Arce the winner, and it only appears to be growing (https://www.as-coa.org/articles/explainer-presidential-candidates-bolivias-2020-special-elections).  Only challenges seem to be from Anez and Mesa.

https://www.paginasiete.bo/nacional/2020/3/26/tse-plantea-que-las-elecciones-generales-sean-entre-el-de-junio-de-septiembre-250911.html Tentative dates 'between' jun7 and Sep 6. This interval (3m) is longer than the typical one between initial and runoffs for a GE, suggesting the first general election could fall somewhere in this interval. Unless it is in the first week, the question closes.

The election has been postponed because of the Covid-19 upheaval. The Electoral Tribunal will decide on new timetabling after discussing with representatives of the political parties, which will then be proposed to Congress. I am not altering my forecast. The situation seems to be unchanged in that Arce looks likely to win the first round without an overall majority; the race is for second place between Anez and Mesa; and the second round between Arce and either Anez or Mesa is wide open. I still think Mesa is more likely to win the first round than the incumbent Anez. Whether there is a Covid-19 effect and if so whether it will work for or against Anez may become clear in the next few weeks.

Bolivia extends its nationwide quarantine thru April 30.
https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
An election in May is unlikely in my opinion. Assuming the election is pushed past June 13 when this question ends.

Currently Bolivia has 210 covid-19 cases and 15 deaths, with roughly 15 new cases/day. The assumption is that the May ballot will be postponed beyond the close date of this question (June13). Bolivia currently in lock down.

Election postponed: https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/bolivia-suspends-presidential-election-due-to-virus-lockdown/ar-BB11AvzZ
Will this question be extended so we can forecast results with the new timeline?

Hattip @fisherdbus - I'll take cousin Vinny's word that the election will be pushed.
Bolivia currently has 107 cases of covid-19 per WHO on April 1.
My Bolivian friend who talks to his brothers there says they have moved the election until August. Is the end date going to be past thst or close June 14?
Closing Date June 14. No election is going to take place by then.

March 28 Boliva has 74 cases of covid-19 and has suspended the election for at least 14 days from March 22.
So the election could be pushed to beyong May 3 to re-evalute in early April.

Brazil media reported recently that government in Bolivia has suspended May presidential vote indefinately. Here is link in Brazilian Portuguese https://www.jb.com.br/internacional/2020/03/1022915-novo-coronavirus-faz-bolivia-suspender-eleicoes-por-tempo-indeterminado.html
Ok. Might get election in this year but it might get put off till next year.

Election delayed. It was supposed to be May with run-off if needed in June. Run-off was likely. The Legislature would have to pass legislation to set a new date. Unlikely process will be done by closure of this question. Now if you are going to extend this question past June 14 I will put my candidate percents back where they were.

Bolivian Elections were postponed 3/21. How will this question be scored with an uncertain date to resume and a close date of 6/13.      Hattip @jpm93 for the pointer below:
https://www.abc.es/internacional/abci-bolivia-aplaza-sin-fecha-elecciones-3-mayo-coronavirus-202003212109_noticia.html

Bolivia currently has only 19 Covid-19 cases, if they can contain the disease perhaps they can hold a May election.
If not, then I assume some other outcome would prevail with elections postponed for 6 months.

Recent binary polls suggest the second round will be close. I have taken a few points away from Áñez. As Arce climbs in the first round polls and the image of Morales improves, some voters who are not necessarily strong Morales supporters may start thinking Áñez, whom some feel is racist, shouldn't have become president in the first place. I won't be surprised if Mesa wins the second round, but I am giving Arces a slightly better chance because the anti-Arces vote is likely to be split in the first round so even though it is highly improbable that Arces will score anywhere near 50% in that round he will nonetheless probably come first by a large margin, gaining momentum.

March 17 Bolivia has 11 active covid-19 cases. My assumption is that the May and June elections will be postponed as disease cases mount. As with other countries social distancing may become fashionable in the next month.
Economist suggests Arce is polling best, but not likely to win on first ballot, second ballot everything changes.
Hattip @Sergio-Guzman for a cogent analysis of the situtation.

Evo Morales, though removed from the presidency, still carries public opinion in Bolivia. His endorsement of Arce is likely to be the principal argument for voters who believe Morales was unfairly ousted from power. The MAS party has remained a solid supporter of Morales and has a well-organized party structure that commands voter discipline. Although Añez is likely to unite the opposition, Carlos Mesa is likely to split the opposition vote even further.

Who will win the 2020 Bolivian presidential election?
I have decided a random number generator is the best way to approach all election questions.
Arce seems to be the favorite based on opinion polls and sentiment; will revise as I accumulate more information

It looks like a fairly polarised election based on either continuing or breaking with the legacy of Evo Morales. Arce is the continuity candidate. There is more support for breaking with the past, but it is spread among several candidates. Arce is on about 30% right now. Áñez and Camacho combined have slightly more support than Arce. Some assumptions I will make, based on the electoral system and current polls rather than knowledge of the country:
- Nobody will win the first round outright
- The runoff will be between Arce and another candidate According to the most recent poll info I could find (https://www.lostiempos.com/actualidad/pais/20200223/mesa-anez-se-imponen-arce-segunda-vuelta, in Spanish) Arce would lose to Áñez or Mesa but would beat Camacho.
So the key question is who comes second to Arce in the first round. If we assume Arce wins the first round and use it as a poll for who comes second, we get Áñez on 37%, Mesa on 39% and Camacho on 24%. And if we assume Arce would beat Camacho while the other two would beat Arce, that gives us Áñez on 37% to win, Arce on 24%, Mesa on 39% and Camacho on zero. Since that is clearly a rather simplistic model (the polls can change, and it doesn't seem right to rule out a major candidate entirely) I have reallocated a few points from the others to Camacho, and other outcomes. There have been debates about whether some of the anti-Arce candidates should even be standing, so it's possible there may be withdrawals, which the model doesn't factor in. So I will keep watching this space.
Recognizing that I don't have a clue, I'll temper my forecast until I learn more.
Updating forecast for the "Someone else or another outcome" as I can't justify a 0% forecast under Cromwell's Rule :).

I don't believe that many people are happy with Jeanine Anez and her running in this election.  I've given her a bit of a boost over Camacho and Mesa because she's, "the incumbent" and may have greater name recognition (plus the "status quo") on her side.  Luis Arce, according to this site () is. "credited with leading Bolivia through its economic boom in which the Andean country averaged GDP growth of 4.9 percent annually between 2006 and 2018 and for being the architect of Morales’ economic policies."  In a poorer country like Bolivia, the economy matters quite a bit.  Therefore, I think that Arce has the best shot of all the candidates. I do not believe, at the moment, that there's any reason for any other outcome (i.e. a military junta).

According to polls
Arce (MAS) 20 to 30%
Mesa 13 to 17%
Añez 12 to 16%
Camacho 6,9 to 17% However, a second round is probable - then non-MAS votes will go to the other one

Arce has topped all four polls held in 2020, and he represents the same party as Morales who won the first round by around 10% in the 2019 election. Anez may make it to the run-off, benefiting from incumbency, but she has been criticised for racism against indigenous people which may lose her votes, giving second place to Mesa who came second in 2019.

Who will win the 2020 Bolivian presidential election?
Hattip to @FredC and @Halito for their enthusiastic endorsements and insights.

Arce likely "power behind  the throne" of Anez and will stay there with lots of gaps in his rez, transgenerational ties with the Santa Cruz "civic committee", trigger happy theocrats an too close to baddies like Branko Marinovic. Sort of a Bolivian version of El Salvador's "Blowtorch Bob" DÁubuisson of 1970s-80s.  It will be tough for Anez to distance herself from him and his clique.  That could start to happen if Arce wants the actual presidency that bad and overshadows Anez.  Depending on who, internationally is supporting an Arce agenda- fronted by Anez- regime, and how neighbors and intl media and ngos, OAS etc position themselves, the right wing machinations could open space for Mesa, and Camacho... but for how long...

Anez has the backing of enough power centers to win the election.   So far she has managed to handle the transition from Morales as best as is possible.  Enough voters have a desire for a new direction and will give her a chance demonstrate what she can do.
